advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD. #3 (NOV. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The BBC Master Compact's educational software, takes children from their first grasp of words and numbers to A-level and beyond.<br> In 84% of U.K. schools, children are already growing up with BBC micros.<br> With a BBC Master Compact at home, your child's ability with computers will progress in leaps and bounds... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1987 price list, including VAT.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD APRIL 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> Waiting for you, all the incredible performance and power of the IMSAI 8080. And at a price you would normally pay for a home music system : $699 in kit, $931 assembled...<br><br> <b>WORLS OF USES : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is a superbly engineered, putting litterally hundreds of applications and uses at your fingertype...<br><br> <b>GROWS WITH YOU : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is designed for many years of pleasure. With its open-chassis engineering, you can expand your system by adding peripherals and interfaces. The 22 slots and 28 amperes power supply mean that you can plug-in todays's plus tomorrow's modules. Right now, you can add a module for displaying color graphics and characters on TV, a ready-to-use keyboard, a cassette tape recorder, small and large printers...<br><br> <b>EASY TO PROGRAM : </b>With our BASIC language, you can operate the IMSAI 8080 quickly and easily. Thechnically knowledgeable ? Use our assembly language to develop sophisticated and unique software.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 816/C VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 816/C version was a multi-user system featuring:<br> - Dual CPU (8085 + 8088) motherboard<br> - 384 KB of RAM, expandable to 1 MB<br> - 2 x 1.2 MB 8" F.D. drives<br> - 9 serial ports<br> - 3 to 16 users expansion<br><br> As the magazine 'computer Age' said, this system was almost twice as quick as an IBM-PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LIFLEAT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pravetz Apple II compatible technology and price are compared with the IBM compatible Pravetz 8C.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b> for the English translation</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTWARE CATALOGUE</strong></font><br><blockquote>AcornSoft software catalogue for the Electron</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARABIC MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>In late 1988, bilingual (arab / french) versions of the TO-7/70 were sold for peanuts. These models could display latin and arabic characters. The keyboard was also bilingual, as well as the Basic !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 64 BITS IN 1983?</strong></font><br><blockquote>After the optimistic 36 Mhz. speed, here is the 64 bits processing power... with 8 bits/Z80 cards. Here also, the 64 bits 'power' is obtained by putting eight 8 bits cards together in the case.<br> Not a very honest way to sell a computer that is no more than a classic S-100 / Z80 based system with some multi-user capabilities.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil 3: three micro-computers in one!"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This japanese advert indicates that there were at least 3 different models sold...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... The 6800 will never win any beauty prizes. It is like the Model 'T' and the DC-3, not pretty but beautiful in function. It is simple, easy to use and maintain and does its job in the most reliable and economical way possible. What more could you want?</font> </blockquote>

computer.colors: 4 (Black, White, Grey, Blink) - 8 for the PMD-85-3
computer.description:
The PMD-85 was a Czechoslovakian personal computer based on the MHB 8080A processor and manufactured by slovakian company Tesla Bratislava.
Several versions were available: - PMD-85-1 (most common) - PMD-85-2 (better keyboard and software) - PMD-85-2A (new motherboard) - PMD-85-3 (new motherboard again, pictured) - Mato (kit of a clone in a smaller case) This machine was well known among kids and fans for its presence in schools in 80's.
Thanks to Monty Jack and Jan Krupka from Czech Republik for info and picture. _______________________

emulator.description: pages of win32 emulator of PMD 85 and compatibles
emulator.name: PMD 85 emulator

emulator.description: Written by Roman Borik & Martin Borik (include many progs and games)
emulator.name: PMD-85 win-emulator beta
PMD 85 hardware simulator/emulator based on AVR ATmega8515 with TV(PAL) output

computer.name: PMD-85

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PMD-85-3 LARGE VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jan Krupka</b> for the PMD-85-3 pictures</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>With the ROM module and the PMD-10 power supply unit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Tape recorder DIN socket<br> • Serial V24 DIN socket. The PMD-85/3 had a special terminal mode allowing it to be connected to SMEP and RVHP (PDP-11 compatible) mainframes<br> • IMS-2 (IEEE 488) connector<br> • Universal parallel bus 0<br> • Universal parallel bus 1<br> • General I/O connector.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER SUPPLY UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>It fits perfectly to back of the computer but unfortunately the design was not so great if you want to connect something to the I/O port. In that case it simply lays somewhere around.<br> Early PMD-85 wasn't shipped this unit, a standard PSU providing +/-5V and +12V was used.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE PMD-85-3</strong></font><br><blockquote>The electronics od the PMD-85 consists of a logic card and an I/O card.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> MHB 8255 for parallel interfaces<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> MHB 8253 timer<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> MHB 8251 USART, serial communication controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 64 KB RAM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> MHB8080 - CPU<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> MH 8228 - bus controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 8 KB ROM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> MHB 8255 - keyboard controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> Composite video output<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> TV RF modulator and output<br> <b><font color="blue">(12)</font></b> External power supply connector.</blockquote>
